LV= has over 5,700 employees 17 UK offices. It is the firm‚Äôs centre of excellence for commercial motor insurance, including company car fleets, vans, trucks and private hire vehicles.¬†

LV=‚Äôs presence in Ipswich began with its acquisition five years ago of the former Highway business, which at the time had around 90 people in the town. After a period of steady growth, the total has increased with a target of 450. Ipswich is now the second-largest claims centre within the group, the largest being in Bournemouth.

Announcing the latest 120 person expansion in Ipswich, Peter Horton, the mutual firm‚Äôs chief operating officer, said Ipswich was chosen from among a number of options as a location for expansion because of the quality of the existing team‚Äôs performance. He was aware of Ipswich as a major centre for insurance and he praised the ‚Äúspirit and calibre‚Äù of the team at the LV= offices, and the high staff retention and low absenteeism figures being achieved

Fat Face.Body:
Shed your 9 to 5 skin‚Ä¶ because when all is said and done‚Ä¶ Better a bad day on the slopes than a good day in the office.

It all began in 1988, two friends desperately trying to avoid working for a living and enjoying all that the French Alps had to offer. The life was way too good to end too soon‚Ä¶ but money was running short. A plan was needed‚Ä¶ design some sweatshirts, sell ‚Äòem at night, ski during the day, stick around till Spring then head for the beach. Fat Face had been born.

We've grown a bit since then, we sell more than just a few sweatshirts these days and we've got a few more stores. But one thing will never change; we design kit for those who love to get out there, stuff that‚Äôs built to withstand the demands of an active lifestyle. So, whether you‚Äôre into extreme sports or just enjoy getting out amongst it our clothes are proudly designed by our team in England with a focus on modern styling and ‚Äòhero‚Äô pieces for your wardrobe.

We care about the detail and we create clothes that are built to last, at prices you can trust. We wash them again and again, until they have that relaxed ‚Äòold favourite‚Äô feel, from new. We believe our clothes are washed in happiness, before they find their way to you. It‚Äôs what makes FatFace different. We like that and we hope you do too.¬†

Tabletop wargaming

It's all about two people facing each other across a battlefield, each attempting to move their models into position to fire upon their opponent's force or attack them in hand-to-hand combat. Greggs.Business Category: Food and Drink, Bakery and Sandwiches
Greggs.Body:
At Greggs, we have big plans for the future and big opportunities available today. Of course, we all know that these are difficult times, but we've continued to grow. How? We put it down to our famous offering, loyal customers and excellent people - together, the perfect recipe for success.

That recipe has helped us become the country's leading retail baker. We specialise in sandwiches, savouries and all sorts of other baker-fresh food on-the-go. We started business in the late 1930s, when John Gregg delivered yeast, eggs and confectionary on his bicycle. After opening our first shop in 1951, we've grown so much that we now have ten large-scale bakeries around the UK supplying the majority of our 1,500 shops...

Millions of hungry customers walk into our shops every single week. And while those shops (and our products) may have changed, we're still just as committed to serving fresh, quality, affordable bakery food. In fact, two thirds of our sales come from the sandwiches we make in our shops, and freshly baked savouries such as pasties and sausage rolls.

You will love the VIP attention, and the female bias and at half the cost of most health clubs, you will even love our prices.Most of all however ‚Äì you will love the super fast results! Situated on Crown Street, the warm pub atmosphere is complemented by the authentic interior illustrating the pub's historic roots. The beer garden is a superb feature offering regulars, shoppers and residents a place to relax during the summer months.

We have a wide selection of diamond, gold, gemstone and pearl jewellery as well as gifts for all special occasions, from Christenings, birthdays and anniversaries to sporting trophies and retirement presents.

We are official stockists for Citizen, Pulsar and Lorus watches.

We always carry a wide selection of quality second-hand and antique Jewellery, Clocks, Watches and Silverware.

New Wolsey Theatre.Body:
The New Wolsey Theatre is a 400 seat theatre in the centre of Ipswich. Since opening in 2001, it has emerged as a national leader recognised for the diversity of its audiences; for engaging with a broad cross-section of theatre-going and non-theatre-going communities. It has also been commended on its nurturing and development of minority artists, as well as the success of their rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll pantomime. Recent musical revivals have included an actor-musician version of Sweet Charity, Jason Robert Brown‚Äôs The Last Five Years, and Made in Dagenham in co-production with Queen‚Äôs Theatre Hornchurch. They have joined forces with six other mid-scale theatres and Graeae to create Ramps on the Moon, an Arts Council funded strategic touring project, with the aim of increasing the engagement and participation of D/deaf and disabled actors, artists and audiences. 2017 saw their own production of The Who‚Äôs Tommy open in Ipswich before embarking on a national tour. There are a range of performances available, with new work presented in their annual PULSE Festival, work suitable for children and families in all seasons, as well as shows currently touring the UK.

As a not-for-profit organisation and a registered charity, they are funded by the Arts Council England, Suffolk County Council and Ipswich Borough Council as well as through the invaluable donations, individual giving and corporate support of their many friends, patrons and sponsors.

For more information and to book your tickets, please visit the website.

ABP.Body:
Associated British Ports (ABP) ‚Äúhandles 120 million tonnes of cargo each year - about a quarter of the county‚Äôs seaborne trade. With 21 ports around the UK, including the short sea ports of Ipswich and Lowestoft in Suffolk, ABP plays a vital role in the country‚Äôs economy. The Port of Ipswich is Britain‚Äôs largest grain exporter and handles a wide range of cargo, particularly aggregates, cement, timber products, animal feed and fertilisers through two major terminals. It also has an environmentally-friendly treatment plant for timber products from Scandinavia and the Baltics.



The Port of Ipswich, situated at the head of the River Orwell and 12 miles from the open sea, is within a short sailing time from the North Sea shipping lanes. The major trunk roads A14 and A12 are both within easy reach and have connections to the M1 and M25 respectively. The port also has an active rail line at its West Bank.

Come and visit Ipswich County Library in Northgate Street.

As well as borrowing fiction and non-fiction books (which you can also reserve and renew online), you can borrow DVDs and CDs, use our free wi-fi and use a computer.

There are loads of regular and one-off events and activities including: bookstart sessions for children and families, reading groups, social activities for older people and plenty of surprising and engaging things to do year round.

You can also access our large reference section, use our Northgate Room for quiet study (which also has wi-fi) and borrow copies of plays and music vocal scores from the Music and Drama service.

You could also use the new Enterprise + Innovation Hub in Ipswich County Library which, has been named The Carnegie Room. Located on the recently adapted second floor of the library, the hub provides three main services: hireable meeting space, business advice and information, and a communal ‚ÄòMakerSpace‚Äô (named ‚ÄòThe Lab‚Äô) which contains 3D printers, computer coding kits and professional sewing machines. This space has been created to cater for the diverse needs of businesses, organisations and individuals. Larger businesses may be looking for neutral locations to meet with clients, smaller businesses and start-ups may not have their own professional premises and require economical and central meeting space for group work and interviews.

The hub aims to provide somewhere to suit all these needs with three meeting rooms, a presentation suite, a hot-desk space, a large breakout area and a dedicated kitchen.

Take a look at the website for more details of our services and activities including information on how to book a space in the hub and how to download free eBooks and music.

Ipswich Town Football Club.Body:
Ipswich Town Football Club is an English professional football club based in Ipswich, Suffolk.

The Club was founded in 1878 and turned professional in 1936, and was elected to join the football league in 1938.

Ipswich Town¬†has an impressive track record and¬†won the English league title in 1961‚Äì62, and have twice finished runners-up, in 1980‚Äì81 and 1981-82. They won the FA Cup in 1978, and the UEFA Cup in 1981. In 1991-92, Ipswich Town won the Division Two title and were promoted to the inaugural Premier League season. Ipswich Town were also¬†FA Youth Cup Winners in 1973, 1975 and 2005.

Ipswich Town Football Club enjoys strong and passionate support and has a track record of developing exceptional football talent through its Academy. The Club has an enviable reputation for managerial excellence and stability.

For more information please visit¬†www.itfcdirect.com

¬†

Goals Soccer Centre.Business Category: Things to Do, Sport and Leisure
Goals Soccer Centre.Body:
Goals, near the centre of Ipswich has 11 pitches for all weather 5-a-side and 7-a-side football matches. They are designed to coax even the most committed armchair footballers back into their trainers.¬†Complete beginners to advance players welcome.¬†

Goals also have a range of fantastic 5-a-side leagues to suit all skill levels along with our opening cup, The Ipswich 5-A-Side Challenge where you can win a year's worth of FREE footie.

Morgan Law.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services

Crown Mortgage Management.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Crown Mortgage Management.Body: Crown Mortgage Management provides administration services to financial institutions throughout the UK. We specialise in both residential and commercial mortgage servicing and work with banks, building societies, insurance companies, investment funds, and commercial property specialists. We manage a wide range of mortgage products and have significant experience in managing clients‚Äô strategies across both performing and non-performing assets. Our collaborative and highly-flexible approach is centred around one goal: to help our clients enhance the value of their mortgage portfolios whilst delivering exceptional and cost effective customer experiences. The quality of our work and our responsible approach to business helps minimise risk and reach positive outcomes for all.

Danceeats!.Business Category: Food and Drink, Tea Houses Coffee Shops and Cafes
Danceeats!.Body:
After a strenuous dance class, or a walk along the waterfront, why not pop into the danceeats! caf√©?

Hot, cold and alcoholic drinks, homemade cakes, delicious pastries, made to order sandwiches, fresh filled jacket potatoes and a choice of daily specials, danceeats! has something for everyone.

FREE WIFI | CHILD AND BUGGY FRIENDLY | OPEN TO EVERYONE

The friendly team look forward to welcoming you to danceeats! on the waterfront.

Please note: Opening times may be subject to change and occasional late night opening on performance nights.

The Forge Kitchen.Business Category: Food and Drink, Best of British, Fine Dining
The Forge Kitchen.Body:
‚ÄòWe love the simple idea of food cooked as nature intended‚Ä¶
No fuss, over smoke and fire, with a pinch of salt and pepper‚Äô

Born from the heat, flames and stripped back elements found in the Blacksmith‚Äôs forge, our concept is simple - food cooked as nature intended, no fuss, over smoke and fire with just a pinch of salt and pepper, or go full Forge with something a whole lot more indulgent...
It‚Äôs your choice - Forge it your way.
At the bar, a selection of seasonal and smoked cocktails, craft beers and hand-picked wines.

It's time to re-think the steakhouse.¬†

Join us on the journey and follow our daily work at The Forge...

Food Served:

Monday ‚Äì Saturday, 12pm ‚Äì 10pm
Sunday, 12pm ‚Äì 8pm

R3.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
R3.Body: The R3 Group sets out to redefine the financial services market with our fresh approach to aligning people, processes, capital and systems. Bringing together our combined expertise we can confidently deliver dynamic, relevant customer solutions to affinity brands and product manufacturers.

WNS Global Services (UK) Ltd.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
WNS Global Services (UK) Ltd.Body: WNS is a strategic partner for managing complex processes that directly impact the clients‚Äô bottom-line. An end-to-end vertical approach to service delivery, technology-led BPM solutions and a client-centric client-partner approach enable us to deliver business value to many of the world‚Äôs leading companies. We are passionate about building an organization that is valued by our clients, employees, business partners, investors and the community at large. Our management team comprises accomplished professionals from leading global organizations. Each member brings deep business acumen and outsourcing domain expertise, which enables us to drive outperformance in our clients' businesses.

Poundgates.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Poundgates.Body: Pound Gates provides insurance broking and risk management services to corporate clients. As well as dealing with a wide range of trades and industries we have a number of tailored solutions for specific trade sectors. We can distribute some of our niche products through UK brokers.

Buck Consultants.Body: Within Xerox, Buck is the consulting strength of the Human Resource Services (HRS) division. Buck offers advisory, technology, and administration solutions to help you effectively manage your programmes while engaging your employees in their health, wealth, and career. By integrating our HR consulting know-how with HRS' core services, we can offer additional innovative and customised solutions to help you overcome your HR challenges. Together, we can ensure you have the right people in the right positions at the right time to save money and achieve your business goals.

Chelsea Building Society.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Chelsea Building Society.Body:
We are proud to be part of one of the largest Building Societies in the UK, Yorkshire Building Society, following the merger on 1st April 2010. Our business is built on strong values and we have a long standing culture of giving our customers fair treatment.

As a building society we don't need to answer to external shareholders. Our priority is and always will be with our members - people like you who've taken out one of our savings or mortgage accounts.

What's more, our merger with Yorkshire Building Society means that you can trust Chelsea to look after your money. While you continue to enjoy all the advantages of Chelsea's high quality personal service, not to mention a range of accounts designed to suit your needs, behind the scenes you'll benefit from the added support of an organisation with assets of over ¬£30 billion.

We also show our commitment to our members by playing an active role in the communities in which we have a presence, supporting charities and good causes through Yorkshire Building Society Charitable Foundation

Hays.Body:
Specialist recruitment is all about people. Over 7,900 people make up our worldwide team, working out of over 247 offices in 33 countries; we share ideas, knowledge and experience across businesses and territories to deliver outstanding results.

Our people work with job seekers and employers to place the right people in the right jobs; we invest heavily in equipping our staff with the skills to perform to the highest standards while developing their careers.

We serve over 20 specialisms, covering everything from accountancy and finance to construction, IT, education and healthcare. Across many of these sectors, we also have further specialised teams dedicated to public services, not-for-profit, executive and international recruitment.

Providing excellent customer service underpins our business and is an area we monitor closely in order to maintain our position as market leader. Our customers benefit from the specialist sector knowledge of our consultants and our extensive office network and industry contacts.

Charles Stanley.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Charles Stanley.Body: We are one of the UK's leading independently owned, full service stockbroking and investement management groups, advising on substantial client funds. Prudent management, an uncomprising commitment to our clients and our long term financial stability drive our corporate success. Our clients benefit from our objective advice, high quality service and the closing working relationship we maintain with them.

MET-RX.Body: Sports nutrition specialist and fitness and weight management.

Suffolk New Academy.Body: Suffolk New Academy is a secondary school with academy status in the Chantry area of Ipswich in the English county of Suffolk. The school educates children aged 11 to 16 and has around 980 pupils.¬†

Copleston High School.Body: The principal aim of the school is to enable all students to achieve their best. This is brought about by continually developing a stimulating curriculum supported by the highest possible standards of teaching and learning. A warm, caring and vibrant environment is created so that students may thrive and where every student really does matter. An excellent range of curricular, extra-curricular and student voice opportunities ensure that all our students can flourish. Student successes are celebrated in as many ways as possible through posters around the school, achievement assemblies and through wonderful celebration evenings emphasising that we value all students as individuals.

Ipswich Academy.Body: As a school which is part of the Learning Schools Trust (LST) partnership of Academies (Hampton and Twickenham Academies in Richmond, London opened in September 2010 and The Elizabeth Woodville School in Northamptonshire joined the Trust in December 2012), we believe that young people are capable of amazing things and it is our job to see that they are given the right opportunities, facilities and support to achieve more than they ever thought possible. Students are at the centre of everything we do.

Northgate High School.Body: Northgate's traditions go back to the early part of last century and we still place great emphasis on traditional values such as good behaviour, hard work, adherence to the uniform, high expectations and respect for others. We believe that these basics, mixed with stimulating teaching and learning, a strong pastoral support system and extensive extra-curricular opportunities, provide an environment in which our pupils and students can thrive.

Ormiston Endeavour Academy.Body: Ormiston Endeavour Academy is an 11-16 secondary school located in Ipswich. The Academy is supported by sponsor, Ormiston Trust, which provides expertise and a network of Ormiston Academies across the UK. Ofsted inspectors declared the school was improving steadily across most areas.

Stoke High School.Body:
Stoke is a relatively small secondary school with 725 students. We pride ourselves on being a very friendly school and have been consistently commended on our excellent care and guidance. We are committed to providing a safe yet challenging learning environment where all our students can achieve. Our aim is to ensure that all students leave having made good progress with good academic qualifications and the wider skills needed for life.
¬†

Westbourne Academy.Body: We wish to be a school that places learning at the centre of what we do. We will know the capabilities of all students and support them to aim higher. Through the curriculum, extra curricular opportunities, the pastoral system and the healthy ethos of the school, we aim to turn out mature and emotionally literate young adults equipped to face life's challenges.

Ipswich School.Body: Ipswich School is a co-educational day and boarding school for girls and boys from 2+ - 18 years. ¬†For over 600 years, we have been providing a first class education.¬† The Senior School was judged ‚Äòexcellent‚Äô in all areas, according to the Independent Schools Inspectorate, November 2014.¬† This is the top grade independent schools can achieve.¬† The school offers opportunities in music, sport, drama and a wealth of co-curricular activities. ¬†In 2015 our under 18 girls were national indoor hockey champions and our under 16 boys were runners up. ¬†Academic success is also important with 100% of pupils achieving at least five A* - C grades including Maths and English in the summer 2014 exams. ¬†¬†

Ipswich High School For Girls.Body: Ipswich High School is a girls' independent school located at Woolverstone, near Ipswich. It was founded in 1872 and is one of the schools of the Girls' Day School Trust. It is ranked 91st nationally by the Financial Times independent schools list. The school takes girls aged 3‚Äì18 years, providing both primary and secondary school education, as well as a nursery and sixth form. The school has some 600 pupils.

Meadows Montessori School.Body: The Meadows is a small independent Primary School on the outskirts of Ipswich, Suffolk. It caters for children between 4¬Ω and 11 years of age. The school follows the ethos and teaching methods of Montessori education and aims to provide each child with an individual learning experience.

St Stephen's Church.Body: St Stephens Church was built in the 15th and 16th century and is now converted into the Tourist Information Church. In the Church Chancel there is a splendid monument to Robert and Mary Leman who dies on the same day in 1637. Robert Leman was one time Sheriff of London.

St Nicholas Centre.Business Category: Food and Drink, Tea Houses Coffee Shops and Cafes, Professional Services, Conference Venues
St Nicholas Centre.Body:
This Grade II* listed former church was bought by the Church of England in Suffolk in 2000. The stunning glass Sanctuary was added to link the Diocesan Office to the former church creating a centre for both business and entertaining.

The stunning church now boasts a venue hire and a charming cafe.

St Margaret's Church.Body: St Margaret's is a fine medieval Church in town dating from 1300 with the tower added in c.1400 and other parts in 1450. Donations from over the years have made St Margaret's fascinating, with numerous interesting artefacts. The C15 double hammer beam roof, decorated on 1695, is the crowning glory.

Gemini Ghost Tours.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Gemini Ghost Tours.Body:
Gemini Ghost Tours run on the first Thursday of every month, starting at 8pm outside the Tourist Information Centre.

Ipswich is the oldest permanently settled town in England, and so has a rich history that will be explored on these tours.

The tours explore some of the strange phenomenon that ‚Äòhaunt‚Äô some of the towns buildings, with the chance to investigate some of the ‚Äòspirits‚Äô behind some bars as well. Tickets for the tour cost ¬£7, and can be purchased here or at the tourist information centre.

Orwell Lady River Cruises.Business Category: Food and Drink, Best of British, Things to Do, Family Days Out, History and Heritage
Orwell Lady River Cruises.Body:
Cruise the River Orwell ‚Äì voted one of the most beautiful and historic rivers in England ‚Äì aboard the motor vessel Orwell Lady. Cruises depart Ipswich Waterfront, passing through the lock gates, and onto the river, under the stunning Orwell Bridge, through areas of outstanding natural beauty and wildlife, to the bustling ports of Felixstowe Harwich. Enjoy the river from Orwell Lady‚Äôs open top deck or undercover saloon. There is a licensed bar serving hot/cold drinks and snacks. Cruises come with an informative commentary (where appropriate).

Regular return public trips between April and October to Harwich Harbour, Pin Mill or the Orwell Bridge. Also music nights, English Afternoon Tea and Sunday Buffet Lunch cruises.

Tickets and information from website (http://www.orwellrivercruises.com/bookonline.htm), Ipswich Tourist Information Centre (01473 258070) or CoffeeLink on the waterfront.

Sailing Barge Victor.Business Category: Things to Do, Family Days Out
Sailing Barge Victor.Body:
Enjoy the beautiful River Orwell in a style and pace of a bye gone era aboard the Sailing Barge Victor. Victor was built in Ipswich in 1895 and is now fully restored and equipped to high standard for passenger leisure with comfortable, covered saloon, galley, well stocked bar, and ample open air accommodation.

Choose from a variety of cruises to suit all tastes throughout the spring and summer ‚Äì including Picnic Cruises, afternoon Cream Tea Cruises and evening Supper Cruises. In the winter join our ‚ÄúBirds by Barge‚Äù specials ‚Äì watching wildlife with an expert from the RSPB on board.

Tickets and information available form the Tourist Information Centre.

The Ancient House.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
The Ancient House.Body:
The Ancient House, also known as Sparrowe‚Äôs House, is a Grade I listed building dating from the 15th century located in the Buttermarket area. In 1980 the building was acquired and restored by Ipswich Borough Council.

The earliest reference to a house on the site can be found in the 14th century, when it was owned by the knight, Sir Richard of Martlesham. In the 16th century the house was owned by a string of local merchants, including George Copping who acquired the property in 1567. It was Copping that commissioned the paneling of the ground floor room at the front of the house. He also built the 'long gallery'. The Sparrowe family became the owners of the house in 1603, and continued ownership for the next 300 years.

The decorative plasterwork (pargeting) and carving added in the 17th Century is one of the finest examples in the UK. The interior includes 16th Century wall paintings and further examples of carving and pargeting, and is also home to occasional art displays and exhibitions. The building features four panels representing the continents of Africa, Asia, Europe and America, (Australia hadn‚Äôt, at the time, been discovered).

The house also has the Royal Arms of King Charles II on the side of the building which was added in around 1660.

Unitarian Meeting House.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Unitarian Meeting House.Body:
As one of Ipswich‚Äôs most important historic structures, this Grade I listed building is one of the finest surviving Dissenters' Meeting Houses in the country. The House was opened in 1700 by John Fairfax, and much of its original structure remains intact. The interior has many impressive and original features including the spy hole used to keep watch for attackers‚Äô or hostile officials and a richly carved and decorated high pulpit surrounded by box pews and a large three-sided gallery.

Ipswich Unitarian Meeting House retains its original aspect and character more or less intact. This adds to its rarity for few such Meeting Houses have survived, and fewer still without drastic alteration. The rarity is heightened still further by its timber-frame construction. It is believed to be the only remaining example of a purpose-built timber-framed Dissenting Meeting House of its period

The Willis Towers Watson Building.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
The Willis Towers Watson Building.Body: Ipswich is home to the Willis building, designed by the internationally renowned architect Norman Foster. The building was constructed between 1970 and 1975, and¬†was said to be the start of a ‚Äòhigh-tech architectural style‚Äô. The building is a unique shape,¬†occasionally referred to¬† as 'the piano'¬† and¬†sits next to the equally important¬†Grade 1 listed Unitarian Meeting House. In 1991, the Willis Building was declared a Grade 1 building, meaning two of Ipswich‚Äôs most renowned buildings sit directly next to each other. When it was listed, it was one of only two buildings under the age of 30 to be given this status.

Jerwood Dancehouse.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Jerwood Dancehouse.Body:
Jerwood Dancehouse is DanceEast's new permanent home at the former Cranfields Mill site on the regenerated Ipswich Waterfront. The Jerwood DanceHouse was designed by John Lyall Architects and officially opened with a weekend of celebrations on Saturday 10 October 2009.

An inspiration for the architect, John Lyall and developers Wharfside regeneration, was the image of the white lighthouse, typical of the East Anglia coast. The tower, with its white fa√ßade and accents of brightly coloured render reflected in the water, is also an echo of the traditional lighthouse that Lyall became familiar with during family holidays spent at Southwold. 'The building had to respond to the acres of air and water in front of it,' he explains.

University of Suffolk Waterfront Buildin.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
University of Suffolk Waterfront Buildin.Body:
The Waterfront building, located in the heart of the bustling Ipswich Waterfront, opened in 2008 and was the first dedicated teaching, learning and social space for University of Suffolk.

It features an unusual curved structure, multicoloured windows and a sedum roof that enhances the site‚Äôs biodiversity and attenuates surface water.

The 10,500 square metre building has six floors, two main lecture theatres each seating one hundred and forty people, and thirty-four tutorial and teaching rooms seating between eighteen and eighty people.

It is most definitely a new ‚Äòmust see‚Äô of Ipswich!

Old Custom House.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Old Custom House.Body:
The Old Custom House is now the offices of Ipswich Port Authority and was opened in 1845.

Whilst the Waterfront area has recently undergone a massive regeneration with restaurants, a hotel, marina and new homes, the Old Custom House still stands as a reminder of the historic significance of the River Orwell to Ipswich history.

The classical style of the building is particularly impressive from the dockside, with its four columned porticos bearing the Ipswich Coat-of-Arms of lion rampant and the stern of three ships supported by sea-horses, a reminder of the town's maritime heritage. Architectural features include a striking red and cream brick design and a raised four-column portico displaying the Ipswich Coat of Arms. The building is Grade II listed

Pykenham Gatehouse.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Pykenham Gatehouse.Body: The Pykenham gatehouse was built in about 1471 for William Pykenham, Archdeacon of Suffolk, as the entrance to his residence, it was then restored by the Ipswich Building Preservation Trust. The Ipswich Building Preservation Trust carried out a major restoration project in 1982-3. The 15th Century timber framing the gatehouse was restored in addition to the original staircase being discovered during this work. The trust now uses the premises for its headquarters as does the local civic society.

Wolsey's Gate.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Wolsey's Gate.Body: Wolsey's Gate is a Scheduled Ancient Monument named in honor of Cardinal Thomas Wosley. Cardinal Wolsey is best known as King Henry VIII's Chancellor - effectively the second most important man in Tudor England. He was born in Ipswich and had great plans to build a college in town to rival Oxford. Unfortunately it was torn down during the Reformation, and all that remains today is Wolsey's Gate and St Peter's Church, which was to be the college chapel.

Ipswich Town Hall.Business Category: Professional Services, Conference Venues, Things to Do, Arts & Culture
Ipswich Town Hall.Body:
During the day the Town Hall presents two unique galleries that feature contemporary artists from the region and beyond. It also hosts a Tea Room in Gallery 1, where you can enjoy a coffee whilst immersing yourself in the works of art on display.

The Town Hall provides spaces for events, weddings and conferences in a wide selection of rooms including the Grand Hall which is situated in the Corn Exchange. These can be hired out from a basic room hire to a full package deal to meet your requirements. The Ipswich Town Hall forecourt can be hired for events and promotions.

These rooms are available to hire seven days a week and can cater for small groups of six people up to our largest capacity of 1076. All our rooms have flexible layouts, except for the cinemas and the balcony of the Grand Hall which have fixed seating.

Access All Arts is a bi-monthly event taking place at Ipswich Town Hall, providing families with a free day out. Creative activities include; craft workshops, live performances, Suffolk Craft Society, music workshops and art and photography exhibitions.

Blackfriars.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Blackfriars.Body:
The ruins of a 13th-16th Century Friary Church are the only substantial remains of a medieval community's foundation in Ipswich. The church of the Dominicans, the Blackfriars, whose Friary of the Blessed Virgin lay to the south of Tacket Street, was excavated by archaeologists in the 1980s. Five monasteries once stood in Ipswich and none of them survives today. Only the ruins of the Blackfriars Monastery give an idea of what these medieval monasteries looked like while the others have completely disappeared.

In 1263, the Friary was founded and remained there for over 250 years. In the 16th Century, Henry VIII ordered to dissolve the monasteries and give their property to the state. After the closing in 1537, the monastery buildings were left standing - unlike their church of St. Peter and Paul whose ground was used to build a college. But in the 17th century they fell into disuse and some of them were quickly pulled down. After some decades, only the four arches of the Friary remained visible. It wasn‚Äôt until the 1980s that the rest of the monastery was uncovered again and preserved. These measures also uncovered one of only three surviving stone altar structures in Suffolk.

The Cornhill.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
The Cornhill.Body:
The Cornhill has been at the centre of the town's life since Anglo-Saxon Times, and has been the focus of markets, public meetings, fairs and civic ceremonies. It was here in 1555-56 that the "Ipswich Martyrs" were burnt at the stake for their Protestant beliefs and in 1644 Widow Lackland was burnt on the orders of Matthew Hopkins the notorious Witchfinder General. The Town Hall and Old Post Office, two grand Victorian buildings, flank the Cornhill.

In medieval times the Cornhill, or Market Hill as it was also known, became the centre of trade and local government in Ipswich. This market place was the site of the medieval pillar cross of stone erected about 1510. The cross was replaced in 1628 by another more elaborate structure which stood towards the east side of Cornhill until 1812. The Cornhill is still in use today, and is the site of a popular market held every Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

The Corn Exchange.Business Category: Things to Do, Arts & Culture, Entertainment
The Corn Exchange.Body: The Corn Exchange hosts a range of spectacular live events and performances and most recently it has been the stage for the notorious political debate program, Question Time. Also located to the back of the Corn Exchange, the Ipswich Film Theatre boasts a fantastic atmosphere. With licensed bar and regular showings of independent and Hollywood productions this venue offers visitors and residents a unique evening out for something different from the mainstream multiplex experience.

Isaac Lords Crossway Warehouse.Body:
Built in the 15th and 16th Century was Isaac Lord‚Äôs Warehouse and Merchant House, located on Ipswich waterfront and is now known as Isaacs on the Quay. The buildings are full of historic artefacts including the restored Machine Room, which has recently opened as a brewery.¬†

The Isaac Lords complex is the best example of a Merchants House, warehousing and sales room (Auction House) in the country.

The Merchants House faces Fore Street (the Foremost street in Ipswich), the warehouses face the Wet Dock for the import / export of merchandise.

The Giles Statue.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
The Giles Statue.Body:
The Giles Statue, also known as 'The Grandma Statue', depicts the popular cartoon family from famous Ipswich-based illustrator Carl Giles, Britain's best loved cartoonist 

Carl Giles drew weekly topical cartoons and comic strips for the Daily Express and Sunday Express that often included characters from his fictional 'Giles Family' of which the Grandma was the most popular character. Other characters from the family that also feature on the statue are The Twins, Lawrence and Ralph and Rush the dog.

This bronze statue depicting Gile's most beloved characters was unveiled in 1993, just 2 years before the cartoonist died. The statue is positioned so that Grandma is looking up at the studio window of the former East Suffolk House where Giles used to work, above what is now a Costa Coffee shop.

Oblensky Statue.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage

Wolsey Statue.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Wolsey Statue.Body: A new memorial to Cardinal Wolsey by sculptor David Annand was recently erected on Curson Plain at the corner of Silent Street opposite where Wolsey lived in his childhood. This memorial is a life-sized bronze statue of Cardinal Wolsey, shown seated facing south towards St Peter's Church (which Wolsey annexed as the chapel of his College of Ipswich), teaching from a book, with a cat at his side. It was unveiled in 2011.

Ipswich Art Gallery.Business Category: Things to Do, Arts & Culture, History and Heritage
Ipswich Art Gallery.Body:
The Ipswich Art Gallery is an exciting new contemporary gallery with a changing programme of art exhibitions featuring works of international importance and as well as providing a unique stage for local artists to show their work and to showcase the region's artistic talents.

The Ipswich Art Gallery provides access to challenging and thought-provoking experiences from the world of art and over a range of media. The major focus is for modern and contemporary collections, inspiring all who visit.

Admission is Free

The Museum Gift shop is open during gallery hours and stocks a range of souvenirs and related reading material.

Ipswich Museum.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Ipswich Museum.Body:
Explore Ipswich's past with stories that will inspire you. This fascinating and unique museum ‚Äì with FREE entry - gives you the opportunity to meet the famous Wool-I-AM, the woolly mammoth, Rosie the Rhino, the elegant towering giraffe and other wonderful curiosities from the natural world.

Go on a journey through Suffolk's past from the Iron Age to the Romans and Saxons. This museum gives a fascinating insight into the town and surrounding area's intriguing past.  Discover more about past civilisations across the globe, you can even take a trip down the Nile in the Egyptian Gallery.

Next door is the Ipswich Art Gallery, which hosts exhibitions and workshops.

Suffolk Aviation Heritage Display Centre.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Suffolk Aviation Heritage Display Centre.Body:
Suffolk Aviation Heritage¬† Display Centre is being developed to promote a wider understanding, within the general public, of the County‚Äôs vast aviation related history.

Together with informative displays and special exhibitions, visitors are able to explore previously unrecorded aspects of aviation history.¬†

Opening Times

Every Sunday - 2nd Sunday in March to the last Sunday in October - and Bank Holiday Mondays.

11.00am to 4.00pm

Admission

Free. Advertised Special Exhibitions at small entry fee.

Shop

Aviation related art work. Booklets on Edith Cook and Trimley Heath GCI Station are also on sale.

Ipswich Transport Museum.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Ipswich Transport Museum.Body:
The Ipswich Transport Museum has the largest collection of transport items in Britain devoted to just one town. Everything was either made or used in and around Ipswich, the county town of Suffolk.
The collections also include the Ipswich Engineering Collection; displays and objects celebrating the rich engineering history of Ipswich. The museum has around 100 major exhibits and many small items connected with transport in Ipswich.

The operations of the Museum are supported by the Friends of the Ipswich Transport Museum. The Museum also organises the annual Ipswich to Felixstowe Historic Vehicle Road Run in May each year and a number of special events throughout the year.

Clifford Road Air Raid Shelter Museum.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Clifford Road Air Raid Shelter Museum.Body:
Hidden beneath a Suffolk school playground, among quiet residential streets, the shelter provides a vivid picture of life during World War Two.

The shelter was built in Ipswich during the first three months of the war, and was unusually robust compared to other public provisions. This was partly due to the efforts of the controversial local MP, Richard Stokes, who campaigned for massive public air-raid shelters to be built under Alexandra Park.

After the war, the shelter was sealed up and largely forgotten. It was re-discovered in 1989, when workmen excavating a small pond for the school found one of the original entrances. To everyone's surprise the tunnels were in first class condition.

To check out the opening times Click here

Connells.Body: Connells is committed to delivering the highest levels of customer service and in 1998 joined The Property Ombudsman service in order to further these aims. Over the last six years, the Connells Group has won numerous national Estate Agency Awards including Best Large Estate Agency, Best New Homes Agency, Best Large Lettings Agency and Best Financial Services Agency. Our people are well trained, highly motivated and dedicated to achieving results. Honesty, integrity and a commitment to do their best are typical qualities of a Connells person. They receive excellent training and regular coaching throughout their career and enjoy the support and encouragement of experienced managers, partners and directors. Above all, Connells people have energy, enthusiasm, drive and determination. They are individual entrepreneurs who work effectively within a team and in partnership with you to achieve a successful outcome.

Leaders.Body:
Leaders is one of the largest independent residential property groups in the UK, with over 120 branches specialising in lettings, sales, buy-to-let and investment finance.

Established as a single branch agency 1983, it has grown by delivering an excellent local property service and by acquiring reputable businesses to bring their service to new towns and cities across the UK.

Leaders has branches across the South East, London, South West, East Midlands, East Anglia and North West; and continues to open branches in new areas.¬†

In 2016 they joined forces with sister company¬†Romans, combining expertise in lettings, sales, new homes, mortgage advisory services and auctions to further enhance the service provided. Both Leaders and Romans are part of¬†Property Services Holdings¬†backed by Bowmark Capital LLP, the group has annual revenues of over ¬£100 million and more than 140 branches across the UK.

As they grow they remain committed to exceptional customer care. All their branches are staffed by qualified and knowledgeable local property experts who embrace the Leaders ethos of providing a professional, high-quality and personal service.

Professional membership of ARLA, NAEA, SAFE agent and The Property Ombudsman gives customers added peace of mind and ensures the organisation meets the highest standards in sales and lettings. ¬†

To find out how they can help you get the best results with selling, letting, buying or renting a home,¬†contact your local branch.

Keystone.Body: Our main Estate Agency office is based in the heart of Ipswich linking the established town centre to the recently rejuvenated waterfront development. We offer a welcoming and professional environment to everyone from the first time buyer who needs a shoulder to lean on to the experienced developer who invests in several properties. We also have another office in Woodbridge, offering our extensive services to a wider area from the coast of Suffolk right down to North Essex. Keystone are proud to be a fully Independent Estate Agents owned and operated by local, experienced and enthusiastic staff.

William H Brown.Body: The business started by offering an auctions and valuation service from modest surroundings. actually within a hut on a stackyard in Ruskington, Lincolnshire, but over the years, the William H Brown name has continued to grow, now with 110 branches and part of the Sequence Group of estate agents. We are seen as one of the most-established names in the industry.

Wherstead Park.Body:
Set in some 17 acres of beautiful landscaped grounds in the heart of Suffolk, an area of outstanding natural beauty, Wherstead Park is the perfect choice for business or pleasure and combines the best of town and country, off junction 56 of the A14, one junction away from the A12 and 3 miles from the centre of Ipswich, with Stansted just over an hour away, making Wherstead Park accessible to all.

The Mansion is an elegant, fully refurbished Grade II listed Georgian Manor House, with views across the river Orwell and open country. Perfect for corporate team building or a peaceful location to conduct interviews, hold an important board meeting or business lunch. The Mansion, with its individually decorated rooms, many with original period features and each one unique, presents a perfect canvas from which to conduct your business.

Alternatively the Atrium, at the heart of Wherstead Park, provides a very unique experience. Good natural light with fully grown ficus trees brings the great outdoors in. Contemporary in style, it‚Äôs a great space for early morning breakfast meetings, private dinners, product launches, exhibitions, fashion shows and musical entertainment and is a very popular choice for wedding receptions.

Christchurch Mansion.Business Category: Things to Do, History and Heritage
Christchurch Mansion.Body:
This beautiful Tudor mansion is the jewel in the crown of Ipswich's historic past boasting over 500 years of history.

Explore the period rooms from the Tudor kitchen to the sumptuous Georgian saloon and the beautifully detailed Victorian wing and much more!

Gaze at the fine collection of art from Suffolk artists including the biggest collection of Thomas Gainsborough and John Constable paintings outside of London.

There is a cafe on site (seasonal opening times) where you can relax over tea or coffee, cakes or lunch or grab a picnic to eat in the park.

Mansion Tours

The Friends of Ipswich Museums offer free short daily tours of the Mansion called 'A Peep into the Past'. These take place at 11am, Tuesday - Saturday and 2pm on Sunday, March to November only.

Full tours can be booked at other times by contacting Christchurch Mansion on 01473 433554.

The Wolsey Art Gallery

The Wolsey Art Gallery (part of Christchurch Mansion) is now open with a permanent display of John Constable's work

Christchurch Park.Body:
Christchurch Park is Ipswich‚Äôs oldest public park, opening in 1895, but was the site of an Augustinian priory as far back as the 12th Century.

Within the park, there are many attractions. There is an upper and lower arboretum - the ‚Äòhorticultural gem‚Äô of Ipswich, providing a tranquil setting in which people can relax and reflect. The park is one of the wildlife hubs of the town, and has over 100 species of birds within it, as well as grey squirrels and foxes, an contains a wilderness area, a children‚Äôs playground and an outdoor nature classroom. The park is also the centre for outdoor entertainment in Ipswich, with summer concerts, free tennis courts and the historic Christchurch Mansion, open free to the public and with a tea room. To find out more go to the Reg Driver Visitor Centre (Bolton Lane entrance). There is a thriving Friends group ‚Äì www.focp.org.uk

 

Christchurch Park can be accessed via entrances at:

  • Soane Street;

  • Westerfield Road;

  • Bolton Lane;

  • Henley Road;

  • Fonnereau Road;

  • Park Road.

Opening times

Christchurch Park opens at 7am every day.

Closing times

Closing times vary according to the season. A whistle is blown when locking time commences so please make your way to the nearest exit.

Please note that the Arboretum gates at Christchurch Park are locked 15 minutes before all other gates.

Chantry Park.Body: Chantry Park is a 50 hectare park on the western outskirts of the town centre. It has been a public park since 1928, and within the grounds sits a 17th Century country house. The park features some grass tennis courts and hosts a number of local cricket matches and the weekly Ipswich Park Runs. During the Summer months, Chantry park is home to a number of large open-air concerts including East Coast Live and McBusted.

Holywells Park.Body:
Holywells Park is situated just north of the Ipswich waterfront area, and has 67 acres of grounds. The park offers water play facilities in the summertime only, a bowling green, and a state of the art children‚Äôs play area. Holywells Park opened to the public in 1936. The former mansion was demolished but a Grade II listed Orangery from the late 19th century still exists for all to see.

Opening times

Holywells Park opens at 7am every day.

University of Suffolk.Body:
The University of Suffolk is¬†an agile, responsive university, custom built for a changing world, absorbing the best of UK university traditions and aligning them with a twenty first century audience and a modern world of employment and entrepreneurship.

Through establishing working relationships with charitable organisations, business and research bodies the University has a rich network to enhance its projects and is¬†growing its reputation for world renowned academic expertise.

The University of Suffolk is a key contributor to its local communities; developing subject areas closely aligned to regional economic priorities as well as contributing to the overall economic growth of the county.

The main University campus is in Ipswich with degrees also being provided at West Suffolk College in Bury St Edmunds, Lowestoft College and Great Yarmouth College.

Ipswich Regent.Business Category: Things to Do, Arts & Culture, Entertainment
Ipswich Regent.Body:
The Ipswich Regent is East Anglia's largest theatre boasting more than 1,500 seats. Located in St Helen's street, the Regent Theatre opened in 1929 and it was among the first UK theatres to play films with sound. Throughout the years the theatres top acts have included the likes of The Beatles, The Walker Brothers and Jimi Hendrix. It became a Gaumont cinema before being saved for live entertainment by the borough council in 1991 and reverting to the Regent name.

It features top names across comedy, music and theatre ‚Äì West End shows at local prices.

In this unique and quirky shop you‚Äôll find products you won‚Äôt find anywhere else, such as True Grace Candles, Wrap cards, Orelia jewellery and Jellycat toys. And what makes LoveOne really special is the large stock of handmade products created by local artists and makers giving these talented people a great place to sell their work. Cathy Frost, owner of LoveOne is keen to encourage people to shop local and visit the fantastic array of independent shops and business on St Peter‚Äôs Street. She is also part of I Make Fun Stuff, helping to organise the street markets and make them a success for the makers and the community. LoveOne is also home to Subterranean Art Gallery and Tram Records.

Willis Towers Watson.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Willis Towers Watson.Body:
Willis is a ‚Äúleading global insurance broker, which has had a significant presence in Suffolk for 40 years - based in an iconic Grade I listed black glass building in the centre of Ipswich.
The company relocated to Ipswich in the 1970s because it was less expensive than London creating a centre of excellence for financial services and insurance companies. Being in Ipswich allows Willis to take advantage of the high quality talent pool available in Suffolk, while still being close to the insurance capital of the world.

Having recently expanded to meet the demands of its growing business the company now employs 1,200 Associates in Ipswich with a further 100 people supporting the running of the Ipswich operation in functions such as IT, catering and security. Globally Willis has a network of offices in 90 countries and operates in over 130, with a global team of approximately 17,000 people serving clients throughout the world.

Mark Parker, Managing Director of Global Service Centres in Ipswich and Mumbai, has worked for Willis for 29 years in various operational roles and returned to his native Suffolk to take up his dream job in April 2011. He said:
‚ÄúDespite the less than optimistic growth forecasts for the world economy in 2013, with operations in every part of the world, Willis is ideally placed to take advantage of growth opportunities wherever they exist. At the end of the day, whatever the economic climate, business will always need insurance protection and we are in the business of offering what we like to call ‚Äúresilience‚Äù to our clients in an increasingly risky world. Insurance is the DNA of capitalism and our bespoke client solutions provide the bedrock that allows companies around the world to invest, innovate, create jobs and think long term. Our global platform helps with managing the economic ups and downs across different countries and regions. We are the first and biggest insurance broker in China and also have businesses in all main regions of the world including North America, Europe, Asia and Latin America‚Äù.¬†

Axa.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Axa.Body:
AXA is the largest insurer in the world and has been ranked as the top insurance brand globally. In the UK, its main lines of business are wealth management, commercial insurance, personal lines insurance and healthcare, with c13.5 million customers and c13,000 employees.

David Williams, AXA Managing Director Underwriting, has been based in Suffolk for 20 years and believes the county has huge potential to grow and support new and existing businesses.

Lush.Body:
We believe in buying ingredients only from companies that do not commission tests on animals and in testing our products on humans.

We invent our own products and fragrances, we make them fresh by hand using little or no preservative or packaging, using only vegetarian ingredients and tell you when they were made.

We believe in happy people making happy soap, putting our faces on our products and making our mums proud. We believe in long candlelit baths, sharing showers, massage, filling the world with perfume and in the right to make mistakes, lose everything and start again.

We believe our products are good value, that we should make a profit and that the customer is always right.
*We also believe words like 'Fresh' and 'Organic' have an honest meaning beyond marketing.

Trongs.Body:
Our Cuisine is in essence and in short the haute cuisine of China. It combines the dishes that originated from the imperial kitchens or were created from the wealth of produce of north China, with all the culinary creations which have been distilled and imported from the vast repertoire of dishes from the outlying provinces: the beef and lamb dishes, the hot plate and barbecues from Inner Mongolia: the crabs and giant prawns from the gulf of Yangtze: the duck dishes from the envirous of Peking: the corn, pastas, chicken and the ‚ÄúGreat White Cabbage‚Äù from Shantung and the plains of North China: the salt-baked and hot-spiced dishes from Rwantung and Fukien, the rich clear broths, and the whole fish and long-cooked meat dishes with their vast accompaniment of vegetable creations from the Yangtze and the ‚ÄúGreat Lakes‚Äù of China.

St Mary-le-Tower Church.Body:
St Mary-Le-Tower is both a parish church with a thriving congregation of people of all ages, and the Civic Church for the town of Ipswich. Its fascinating history and its location in the heart of the town draws large numbers of visitors.

Our congregation is drawn from all around the Ipswich area, coming from a wide variety of backgrounds and religious perspectives, ranging from Evangelicalism through to Anglo- Catholicism. Eastern Angles Theatre Company.Business Category: Things to Do, Arts & Culture, Entertainment
Eastern Angles Theatre Company.Body:
Eastern Angles Theatre Company combines heritage with theatre to make regional stories and hidden histories come to life on stage.

Eastern Angles provide professional rural touring and site-specific theatre with a focus on new writing, new audiences and the development of new talent. Their stories and themes are derived from our sense of place, specifically East Anglia and the East of England.

Since forming in 1982, Eastern Angles have blazed a trail across East Anglia over 30 plus years and expanded to national tours and Edinburgh Festival residencies. They‚Äôve performed at quirky locations including Isaacs pub on Ipswich Waterfront, farmyard barns, airfield museums and even fire stations.

Based in Ipswich at the Sir John Mills Theatre, the company also has a second base in Peterborough at Chauffeur‚Äôs Cottage.

Its current annual programme includes: a new writing theatre tour to village and community halls in the Spring; Platform Peterborough in the Autumn; and a unique comic extravaganza in the Sir John Mills Theatre, Ipswich and Seckford Theatre, Woodbridge over the Christmas season. In between, Eastern Angles also commission new plays, provide workshops for schools with professional actors and directors and create community performances.

Royal Hospital School.Body:
The Royal Hospital School is a leading independent co-educational boarding and day school in East Anglia. The School has a roll of around 700 pupils aged 11-18, 500 of whom are boarders with the rest being day pupils or day boarders. The School occupies a magnificent site on the banks of the River Stour in the Suffolk countryside, a few miles south of Ipswich.

The school was created by Royal Charter in 1694 and the Royal Hospital School moved from Queen‚Äôs House, greenwich (now the National Maritime Museum) in 1933 to a newly built campus in Holbrook.

Waterfront Studios.Body:
¬†

Waterfront Studios is an innovative new creative industries hub that has been developed by the School of Arts and Humanities at the University of Suffolk, in partnership with Ipswich Borough Council, Suffolk County Council and Arts Council England.



It is an ideal opportunity for graduates, alumni, creative start-ups and artists to rent affordable studio and office space.¬†The impetus behind this new hub is to encourage the development of the creative and cultural industries within the region, by providing new networks and business links and creating pathways from education to employment. It aims to develop a vibrant and inclusive artist-led space that welcomes, supports and inspires new arts initiatives.

With an innovative approach towards developing community participation, Waterfront Studios will also host a varied and exciting schedule of seminars, showcases and exhibitions. Members will therefore benefit from networking opportunities and the full support of the University of Suffolk's School of Arts and Humanities Department.

Suffolk Chamber of Commerce in Greater I.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
Suffolk Chamber of Commerce in Greater I.Body:
Business is at the heart of the community and the backbone in driving the Ipswich economy. Therefore, whether you‚Äôre a new start business or a blue chip organisation, it‚Äôs always good to know that you‚Äôve got someone to rely on to help you promote, support and grow your business.¬†

Ipswich Chamber of Commerce, part of the Suffolk Chamber of Commerce, is the largest independent private sector forum in the town, with an aim of supporting the needs of the local business community and in particular its Chamber members.¬†

Ipswich Chamber is in a privileged position to support and represent local business interests. As the voice of Ipswich‚Äôs business community, the Chamber, through its local board, as well as the County Chamber structures, is equipped to react and respond on behalf of businesses to local, regional, national and European issues.¬†

Ipswich Chamber offers members a wide range of services and support to ensure that we always reflect a modern, changing business environment. The breadth and depth of what we offer ensures that members can operate more effectively and productively, secure in the knowledge that they have an¬†active, supportive¬†and well-respected¬†organisation behind them.

Ipswich Chamber of Commerce is THE voice for the Ipswich business community.

The site has origins which pre-date the Saxon era during which time Stoke (Saxon for stockade) was a fortified hill, cut off from the rest of the town by water and marshes.

St Bartholomew's Church.Body: St Bartholomew stands guard over the double door entrance to this grand building. One of the finest churches of architect Charles Spooner, it was consecrated in 1895 but not finished until 1907. Superbly proportioned and ornately finished, the interior is surrounded by brick walls under a lofty roof with space for several alters and shrines.

Allen Gardiner is available for your own exclusive private charter, or individuals may book independently, sharing with other passengers.

Available cruises:

  • 2 hr brunch cruise, 9:30 - 11:30am
  • 3 hr lunch cruise, 12:00 - 15:00
  • 3 hr supper cruise, 16:00 - 19:00
  • 3 hr candlelit dinner cruise, 19:30 - 22:30

At other times, we cater for cruises tailored to our customers‚Äô requirements, such as sunset cruises, happy hours and after work get-togethers ‚Äì just speak to the team.

High standards and an ethically honest approach are vital parts of our success.

EServGlobal.Business Category: Professional Services, Financial and Legal Services
EServGlobal.Body: eServGlobal offers mobile money solutions which put feature-rich services at the fingertips of users worldwide, covering the full spectrum of mobile financial services, mobile wallet, mobile commerce, recharge, promotions and agent management.

East of England CO-OP Opticians.Body: Highly qualified optometrists, cutting edge technology, an incredible range of frames and contact lenses - these are just three good reasons to visit your friendly East of England Co-op Opticians. Visit your local branch today and discover why our customers stay with us, generation after generation.

East of England CO-OP Education Centre.Body:
Situated in central Ipswich, our Education Centre is available for hire for meetings and events, at very competitive rates.

Please visit the website for more information.¬†

Concertus.Business Category: Professional Services, Design Marketing and Media
Concertus.Body: We offer wide ranging professional expertise and knowledge, creating successful solutions that are tailor-made to meet our client needs. Working across a number of specialisms, we are an enthusiastic, passionate and a talented team of property specialists and designers, whom provide a range of services to clients in both the public and private sectors.

Locanda di Parma.Body: Ciao and welcome from "Locanda di Parma" and our Italian "Cucina". Here you can find a real Italian food experience.

Lift Beauty Clinic.Body:
Lift Beauty Clinic is the leading and most reputable beauty salon in the area, previously trading as Carolyn Hammond Beauty Clinic, established in 1987.

Finalists in the 2016 BABTAC and CIBTAC best national large salon of the year.

At Lift Beauty Clinic we offer a wide range of beauty treatments for male and female clients in Ipswich and the surrounding villages. Our extensive treatments range from facials to body treatments and from permanent hair removal to waxing. We work with the prestigious Decl√©or skin care range, renowned in the beauty industry.

Our aim is to pamper you in our exquisite and relaxing beauty clinic and make you feel special with our luxurious treatments.

Caffe Basso.Business Category: Food and Drink, Tea Houses Coffee Shops and Cafes
Caffe Basso.Body: They are a small and friendly local Italian Caff√© located in the heart of Ipswich, ideally positioned between the town centre and the marina. They serve a delicious range of hot and cold food, coffee, drinks, and alcoholic beverages. Why not come in and give them a go?

Byron.Body: We started Byron with a simple mission: to do one thing and do it properly. We serve simple, delicious, juicy hamburgers, made with the best ingredients possible. We may have a few more restaurants these days, but our mission remains the same: to keep serving proper hamburgers, the way they should be.

Coast to Coast.Body: America is home to some mind-blowing food. And we‚Äôre not just talking burgers, steaks and subs (hunger-bustingly good as they are are). We‚Äôre talking about the gastronomic wonders from the lengths of the great states. The sort of stuff you can just can‚Äôt wait to get stuck into. Now to find it, you can travel the 3,142 miles of Lincoln Highway, like we did. Or you can save yourself a few bucks and come on in to see what we found…

Cosy Club.Body:
Our 15th Cosy Club, now part of the collection opened to the public on 22nd August 2016, a Cosy little outdoor terrace area welcomes you along. Just inside, a glass staircase takes you to the top where you‚Äôll be greeted by our wonderful hosts. Disabled access and for those with buggies, can be gained through entering the shopping centre to the side and using the lift ‚Äì we have just as glorious of an entrance from inside the centre too.

Our glorious dark wooden bar is almost the length of the restaurant complimented by golden rails where you can lean and watch over our team whip you up the perfect drink. Just behind this glorious scene lays our restaurant, tucked away and overlooked by our hand carved wooden wall, originally made of stone and recreated for your viewing pleasure.

Did we mention the presence of our illuminating chandeliers? You‚Äôll be sure to find something delightful to look at on every wall. Look out for a rather dashing looking chap in a suit, with a long face…

Prezzo.Body: Prezzo brings a touch of class to Italian casual dining. We set the scene for your get-togethers, gossip, romance and reunions, fuelling the conversation with incredible food and impeccable service €¨to make you feel at home.

Puregym.Body: It doesn't matter if you've never set foot in a gym before or if being among free weights is your second home, every body is welcome. We pride ourselves on providing lots of quality kit, offer over 50 free gym classes each week, 24/7 access, and our memberships are contract-free, so you can continue your fitness journey for as long as you like...and all for one great value price.

Wagamama.Body:
our story

‚Äòkaizen‚Äô, meaning ‚Äògood change‚Äô is the philosophy that sits right at our heart. it shapes every dish we create, and pushes us to find better ways in all that we do. we‚Äôre restless spirits. forever creating and making things better

we‚Äôve been practising kaizen since 1992, when we opened our first doors in london‚Äôs bloomsbury. inspired by fast-paced, japanese ramen bars and a celebration of asian food, wagamama burst into life. we set out to create a unique way of eating. bringing the fresh, nourishing, flavours of asia to all

that was 25 years ago now. two whole decades to sharpen skills and refine recipes. to play with spices and discover tastes. we continue to get better with every day

Flow Energy.Body: We‚Äôve been around since 1998, although we first launched on the stock market in 2006. Since then we‚Äôve been developing world-beating technology. We‚Äôve invested ¬£60 m and hundreds of thousands of man hours into the development of the Flow boiler. Along the way, we‚Äôve launched a home energy business and attracted over 100,000 happy customers. We‚Äôre a company with a long history of innovation and success. Join us on our journey today.
